asset:playlist.asset:title: Resist the Urge to Hire People Like You
asset:playlist.asset:description: Mike’s trying to boost diversity in his team. But while recruiting, he’s drawn to people who are like him. A professional coach offers advice for avoiding this common bias—such as asking all job candidates the same set of questions to objectively assess their qualifications.
asset:playlist.asset:biography:
Coach

Audrey J. Lee is the Boston-based Principal of consulting firm Perspectiva. She is an experienced trainer specializing in communication, diversity issues, and conflict management. A certified mediator, Audrey helps clients manage critical relationships successfully. Past clients include Novo Nordisk, Desutche Bank, and the Illinois Supreme Court, where she designed and facilitated courses on diversity, communication skills, and professionalism. Perspectiva has had a long-term collaboration with the Harvard Negotiation Project, an ongoing effort to improve negotiation skills through real-world conflict intervention.

Before joining Perspectiva, Audrey worked as an intellectual property and litigation attorney at Winston & Strawn in Chicago and Davis Polk & Warwell in New York.

She lives in Boston and is an instructor both in the Harvard Negotiation Institute and lecturer at University of Massachusetts Boston.

She is a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School.

Actors

Google “Mike Morrell” and an American politician, a CIA Deputy Director, and a modern mystic come up before Mike Morrell, actor and improviser, comes into view. Any of these characters are subjects Mike could impersonate with ease. He is the creator/director of “Crime Solving Bear” and the popular “DWA Presents,” better known as “The Drinking Show.” He has filmed over 100 commercials and training videos with roles as varied and diverse as bad nurse, bad paper shredder, and bad employee.

Mike has performed improv and stand-up all over Boston, New York, and Los Angeles. He is the cast member of TheartreSports as well as creator and cast member of the showcase show “UnAuthorized Biography.” He just filmed his first speaking role in a major production.

Cheryl Singleton has been a theater professional for many years. She is a member of The Robert Cycle (improvised Shakespeare) at Improv Boston. She serves as Board Vice President of StageSource, the service organization for the theater community of New England. She is a member of Actors’ Equity.

Cheryl served as business manager for a small theater company in Greenwich Village, New York. She worked as a stage manager and dresser at the American Place Theater and The Women’s Project. Some of her acting credits include work at New Rep, The Huntington, Commonwealth Shakespeare Co., A.R.T., Phoenix Theater Artists with Company One, Zeitgeist Stage, Ryan Landry and The Gold Dust Orphans, Queer Soup, and Our Place Theatre Project. She has performed at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe and been seen/heard on film and television in industrials, voice-overs, and commercials.

Cheryl was elected to be an Amherst Collage Wade Fellow and spent more than four years acting as líaison between the black students, faculty, alumni, and administrators of the college.

Brendan Mulhern is an actor, improviser, and musician. He has worked with ImprovBoston since 2008 and is currently a member of their National Touring Company.

Brendan co-created the two-man improv show “Manthorne and The Baron,” which ran during ImprovBoston’s Comedy Lab.  The production became a Showcase Show featured at Philly Duofest, Del Close Marathon in New York City, and the 3rd Annual Boston Comedy Arts Festival. His Boston theater credits include: “The Haberdasher: A Tale of Derring-Do, “The Seabirds” (Argos Productions); “Deathtrap” and “Money Python’s Spamalot” (The Company Theater); and “T: An MBTA Musical” (A.R.T./Club Oberon). Film credits include “A Terrible Idea” (MMM Productions) and “The Heebie-Jeebies” (Dust Bunny Productions).
